metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin(Huailai station-automatic weather station-40m tower, 2019)
metadata.description:
This dataset obtained from an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Huailai station from January 1 to December 31, 2019. The site (115.7923° E, 40.3574° N) was located on a cropland (maize surface) which is near Donghuayuan town of Huailai city, Hebei Province. The elevation is 480 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), wind speed and direction profile (3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), air pressure (in the box), rain gauge (3 m, south of tower), four-component radiometer (4 m, south of tower), two infrared temperature sensors (4 m, south of tower, vertically downward), photosynthetically active radiation (4 m, south of tower, vertically upward), soil heat flux (3 duplicates, -0.06 m), a TCAV averaging soil thermocouple probe (-0.02, -0.04 m), soil temperature profile (-0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m), soil moisture profile (-0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_3 m, Ta_5 m, Ta_10 m, Ta_15 m, Ta_20 m, Ta_30 m, and Ta_40 m; RH_3 m, RH_5 m, RH_10 m, RH_15 m, RH_20 m, RH_30 m, and RH_40 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_3 m, Ws_5 m, Ws_15 m, Ws_20 m, Ws_30 m, and Ws_40 m) (m/s), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) (μmol/ (s m-2)), average soil temperature (TCAV, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, and Ts_160 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, and Ms_160 cm) (%, volumetric water content).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2019-6-10 10:30. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Guo et al. (2020) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2013) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is calculated over different surface types using observational data?
Example.Answer: An example of calculating aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is based on the Xiaotangshan Experiment, where z0m was calculated over various surfaces using wind profile measurements and the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory. The experiment used characteristic parameters of roughness elements like vegetation height and leaf area index to estimate z0m for different surface components and aggregated the data using a footprint weighting method.

Feature Specification.Answer: multi-layer air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction, atmospheric pressure, rainfall, four-component radiation, photosynthetically active radiation, infrared surface temperature, soil heat flux, multi-layer soil moisture, multi-layer soil temperature

Feature Specification.Answer: structure and spacing of roughness elements, vegetation height, leaf area index

Definition.Question: What are the key elements involved in ensuring data quality and consistency during the collection of meteorological data through automated stations?
Definition.Answer: Ensuring data quality and consistency involves several steps such as marking missing data with a specific placeholder, removing duplicate records, eliminating data that falls outside physical or instrumental limits, and standardizing date and time formats. Questionable data is highlighted for further inspection.

Definition.Question: How is aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) defined and calculated in relation to land surface roughness, and why is it significant for surface flux estimations?
Definition.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is defined as the height at which wind speed, extrapolated from the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. It is calculated using the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory and is significant for surface flux estimations because it describes the surface roughness characteristics, which influence wind turbulence.

Definition.Question: What role does the aggregation of individual roughness element characteristics play in calculating aerodynamic roughness length over heterogeneous surfaces?
Definition.Answer: The aggregation of individual roughness element characteristics, like vegetation height and leaf area index, allows for calculating aerodynamic roughness length over heterogeneous surfaces by using the footprint weighting method, which accounts for directional dependencies and spatial distribution of roughness elements.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in addressing data quality control challenges between the multi-scale surface flux observation dataset and the Xiaotangshan Experiment dataset?
Comparison.Answer: Both datasets emphasize the importance of data quality control, where the multi-scale surface flux observation dataset implements procedures like marking missing data, removing duplicates, and filtering out data beyond physical significance. The Xiaotangshan Experiment, while not explicitly detailed in the metadata, likely involves similar quality control steps to ensure reliable calculations of aerodynamic roughness length. The multi-scale dataset, however, provides explicit quality control measures, while the Xiaotangshan Experiment may focus more on the spatial aggregation and parameter estimation challenges.

Interpretation.Question: How might the data collection methods for multi-layer soil moisture and temperature sensors influence the interpretation of soil heat flux patterns?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection method involves embedding soil temperature and moisture sensors at various depths (2cm to 160cm) and using multiple soil heat flux plates at 6cm depth. This allows for an understanding of vertical soil temperature gradients and moisture distribution, which are crucial for interpreting soil heat flux patterns. Variations in these measurements can indicate changes in soil thermal properties, affecting heat transfer interpretations.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the variation in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) observed over different surfaces inform the development of remote sensing models for land surface flux estimation?
Interpretation.Answer: The variation in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different surfaces indicates diverse roughness characteristics due to vegetation height, leaf area index, and other surface properties. Understanding these variations can inform remote sensing models by providing parameterizations that account for the heterogeneity of roughness elements, improving the accuracy of land surface flux estimations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might data collected from automatic meteorological stations require extensive quality control procedures?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data from automatic meteorological stations may require extensive quality control to address issues like data gaps, duplicate records, and values that exceed physical or instrumental limits. Ensuring data accuracy is crucial for reliable analysis and modeling of atmospheric processes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the need for parameterization of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) in remote sensing and land surface models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Parameterization of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is necessary in remote sensing and land surface models because direct measurements are challenging at local or regional scales. Parameterizations help relate z0m to land surface properties, facilitating more accurate modeling of surface-atmosphere interactions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the lack of data from certain time periods impact the reliability and completeness of a dataset in meteorological studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Missing data from certain time periods could lead to gaps in the dataset that may affect the continuity and accuracy of analyses. It might necessitate the use of data imputation methods to fill in these gaps, which could introduce uncertainties or biases depending on the approach used.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of incorporating multi-layer soil moisture data in enhancing the understanding of surface-atmosphere interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating multi-layer soil moisture data can provide a more comprehensive view of the soil's hydrological status across different depths, enhancing the understanding of water fluxes and energy exchanges between the surface and the atmosphere. This can improve the parameterization of land surface models and increase the accuracy of predictions related to surface fluxes and climate interactions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of collecting detailed soil temperature and moisture data at various depths around meteorological towers?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to provide insights into soil thermal and moisture dynamics, which are essential for evaluating land-atmosphere interactions, soil health, and agricultural practices. This data helps in improving models that predict environmental changes and supports precision agriculture strategies.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to calculate and analyze the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over diverse land surfaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The necessity arises from the significant role of z0m in surface flux estimations for remote sensing and land surface models. Understanding z0m over different land surfaces, especially heterogeneous ones, helps in refining model parameterizations and improving predictions of wind turbulence and related climatic phenomena.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are soil temperature and moisture levels measured and recorded at varying depths in a meteorological data collection setup?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil temperature and moisture levels are measured using sensors buried at specific depths ranging from 2 cm to 160 cm. These sensors are placed south of the meteorological tower and are aligned at various depths to gather detailed soil temperature and moisture data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are taken to calculate and parameterize the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over various land surfaces using meteorological data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The calculation of z0m involves using characteristic parameters of roughness elements like vegetation height and leaf area index. The z0m for individual surface components is calculated first, and then the values are aggregated using a footprint weighting method to provide a comprehensive estimate over the entire field.

Enablement.Question: What technological methods enable the collection of multi-layer soil temperature and moisture data at various depths?
Enablement.Answer: The use of soil temperature and moisture sensors placed at specified depths (2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm, and 160cm) around a meteorological tower enables the collection of multi-layer soil temperature and moisture data.

Enablement.Question: How do automated meteorological stations facilitate the continuous monitoring of weather variables at multiple heights?
Enablement.Answer: Automated meteorological stations mounted on towers, such as the 40m tower, facilitate continuous monitoring by collecting data at a frequency of 30 seconds and outputting it every 10 minutes, covering various heights (3m to 40m) for parameters like air temperature, humidity, and wind speed.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for ensuring the quality and accuracy of meteorological data collected from automated stations?
Enablement.Answer: Conditions such as rigorous data processing, including ensuring completeness of daily data, eliminating duplicates, removing data outside physical or instrument limits, and consistent date-time formatting, are necessary for ensuring quality and accuracy of meteorological data.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in obtaining aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) values for local or regional scales using standard station observations?
Expectation.Answer: It can be difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations because these measurements typically require detailed wind profile data, which may not be available at the necessary spatial resolution. Additionally, z0m is influenced by the structure and spacing of roughness elements, which can vary significantly across different areas.

Expectation.Question: What factors could contribute to the difficulty in achieving consistency in surface flux estimations across various land cover types?
Expectation.Answer: The variation in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) across different surfaces, ranging from urban areas to smooth water bodies, contributes to the difficulty in achieving consistent surface flux estimations. This variability is due to the heterogeneity in the size and spatial distribution of roughness elements, like vegetation and other obstacles, which affect wind turbulence and surface characteristics.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the challenges associated with calculating aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces using data from observational field experiments?
Judgmental.Answer: The calculation of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces is challenging due to the need for extensive data that accurately represents the variability in roughness elements, such as vegetation height and leaf area index. The directional dependence of z0m, influenced by the heterogeneity of size and spatial distribution of roughness elements, adds complexity to the calculations. More data is needed to explore these challenges further.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using automated weather stations for collecting high-frequency meteorological data over agricultural fields?
Judgmental.Answer: Automated weather stations are highly effective for collecting high-frequency meteorological data as they provide continuous monitoring of multiple parameters, such as air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and others. Their installation, like on a 40m tower, allows for comprehensive vertical profiling, which is crucial for understanding atmospheric conditions over agricultural fields. The data collected can be used for various analyses, although challenges in data quality control and handling missing data need to be addressed.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how do data processing and quality control steps impact the reliability of datasets derived from meteorological observations?
Judgmental.Answer: Data processing and quality control are crucial for ensuring the reliability of datasets derived from meteorological observations. Steps such as ensuring data completeness, removing duplicates, and filtering out physically implausible values help maintain data integrity. Consistent formatting of date and time and marking questionable data with distinctive identifiers enhance the dataset's usability for further research. These processes are essential for producing datasets that can be confidently used in scientific analysis and modeling.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how different observational layers in a dataset can impact the measurement accuracy and data quality.
Assertion.Answer: The observational layers, such as air temperature and relative humidity at various heights, provide detailed vertical profiling that can improve the understanding of microclimatic variations. The multiple layers allow for cross-validation and help identify any anomalies or errors, thus enhancing the accuracy and quality of the data.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the significance of the data collection frequency in capturing dynamic atmospheric changes.
Assertion.Answer: A high data collection frequency, like every 30 seconds with a 10-minute output, is crucial for capturing rapid changes in meteorological conditions. This granularity ensures that transient events are recorded and helps in detailed analysis of atmospheric processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methodologies used for ensuring data quality and consistency in datasets related to meteorological observations and surface flux measurements.
Request/Directive.Answer: In the field of meteorological observations and surface flux measurements, data quality and consistency are ensured through several processes: (1) Daily data checks to ensure complete data sets, using placeholders like -6999 for missing data; (2) Removal of duplicate records; (3) Deletion of data that are physically implausible or outside the instrument's range; (4) Standardization of date and time formats, with any questionable data marked in red. These methods ensure reliable and consistent data collection.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the challenges associated with calculating aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces using meteorological datasets.
Request/Directive.Answer: Calculating aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces presents challenges such as the need for extensive data to understand the directional characteristics of z0m. The variation in size and spatial distribution of roughness elements in different wind directions affects z0m. An analytical footprint model is used to address these challenges by analyzing directional characteristics and aggregating z0m over the entire experimental field using footprint weighting methods.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential strategies for parameterizing aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) in land surface models using observational data from various land covers.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies for parameterizing aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) in land surface models include relating z0m to characteristic factors of roughness elements such as vegetation height and leaf area index (LAI). Using data from experiments like the Xiaotangshan Experiment, researchers can develop heuristic parameterizations as references for models. This involves calculating individual z0m for each surface component and aggregating them with a footprint weighting approach to account for heterogeneity in land covers.
